docs.lead_paragraph: At a private Christian high school in this conservative region of southwest Michigan, Gov. George W. Bush brought an overflow crowd of faithful Republicans to their feet today -- though he often sounded like a Democrat. ''We're a nation that says that when somebody can't help themselves, we will as a government,'' he said in Kalamazoo. ''We're a nation that says any time anybody has to choose between food and medicine, that's not right.''

headline.main: In Michigan, a Swing State, Bush Picks Words Carefully

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush has conveyed conservative ideas without using conservative buzzwords that might turn off centrist Democrats and independent voters as he barnstorms through Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK'S most widely quoted advice is contained in the very first words of ''The Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care,'' the 1946 volume that redefined child-rearing in America. ''Trust yourself,'' he told parents. ''You know more than you think you do.'' Spock's famously gentle directives made him a global publishing phenomenon. By the time he died in 1998 at age 94, ''Baby and Child Care'' had sold more than 50 million copies. Among baby boomers, he was equally renowned as a principled political activist for his leadership in the movement to end the Vietnam War.

headline.main: Dr. Spock Lives On in Books; Coming Soon, the Web Site

docs.abstract: Gentle directives to parents given over many years by pediatrician Dr Benjamin Spock form basis for new Web site, DrSpock.com; his widow, Mary Morgan, zealously pursues perfecting site; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE GREEN PARTY A MESSAGE TO NADER VOTERS -- Ralph Nader supporters who worry that they could tip the presidential election to the Republicans are being told in a new advertising campaign that a ''vote for Nader is not a vote for Bush.'' Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate, currently draws about 4 percent in national polls, and some Democrats fear he could siphon enough votes from Vice President Al Gore to give Gov. George W. Bush of Texas the edge in several states with close races.

byline.original: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr

docs.lead_paragraph: Helen Dixon, Winters, Calif., August 1955 ''I was feeling terrible. It was both the heat and the pregnancy -- just a short while after that I gave birth to my second son, who was 11 pounds. I was wondering if this should be just the normal birth, especially since he was such a large baby, or whether I should have a Caesarean. You have funny feelings in those last few weeks. You just can hardly wait until the birth.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00; What They Were Thinking

docs.abstract: Interview with Helen Dixon, on how she was feeling when mother-in-law, Dorothea Lange, photographed her shortly before giving birth to her second son; photo (M)
